details.title: A Non-Central Version of the Birnbaum-Saunders Distribution for Reliability Analysis

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Univ. de Valparaiso, Valparaiso

p: Pierre Guiraud is an Assistant Professor at Universidad de Valparaíso, Chile. He received his M.S. degree in theoretical physics from Université de Provence, Marseille, France, in 2001. He obtained his Ph.D. in mathematical physics from the same university in 2004. He has postdoctoral studies at Universidad de Chile, Santiago, Chile. His main research areas are dynamical systems, and their applications in physics and biology.

authors.name: Pierre Guiraud

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Univ. de Valparaiso, Valparaiso

p: Víctor Leiva is a Professor at Universidad de Valparaíso, Chile. He received his B.Sc. degree in Statistics from Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Chile, in 1991. He finished his Ph.D. in Statistics from Universidad de Granada, Spain, in 1999. He has postdoctoral studies with Professor N. Balakrishnan at McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada; and has been a Visiting Scholar at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, USA. He is directory member of the Statistical Chilean Society. His research interests include distribution theory, cumulative damage distributions, censoring methodology, influence diagnostics, reliability, survival analysis, goodness-of-fit methods, and statistical quality control.

authors.name: VÍctor Leiva

authors.affiliation: Lab. de Analisis Estocastico, Pontificia Univ. Catolica de Valparaiso, Valparaiso

p: Raúl Fierro is a Professor at Pontificia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Chile. He received his Masters degree in Mathematics from Universidad Técnica del Estado, Chile, in 1976. He finished his Ph.D. in Mathematics from Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Chile, in 1986. His research interests include stochastic processes, and their statistical inference.

authors.name: RaÚl Fierro

details.abstract: The Birnbaum-Saunders distribution has largely been applied to material fatigue and reliability studies to relate the time until failure to some type of cumulative damage. This damage is produced by the growth of a dominant crack in material specimens, the propagation of which is due to cyclic patterns of stress. However, the Birnbaum-Saunders model was constructed under restrictive conditions that may not be valid for certain applications. In particular, this model was developed assuming that the crack extension in each cycle has a constant s-mean over time. In this article, we assume the crack extensions in each cycle have a non-constant s -mean. This leads us to introduce a non-central version of the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution. Specifically, a comprehensive description of the properties and characteristics of this new model is presented. The suitability of this non-central distribution is shown by using real, and simulated data.

references.title: A new family of life distributions

context.text: Motivated by the problem of damage caused by vibrations in commercial aircraft, Birnbaum & Saunders [3] presented an ingenious statistical distribution for modeling failure times due to fatigue (fatigue life) in material specimens.
To understand the genesis of the fatigue life distribution, and the motive of our proposal, we next recall some concepts used by Birnbaum & Saunders [3] such as crack, cycle, and fatigue.
For more details about the physical aspects of the fatigue process, see Mann et al. [21, pp. 150–152], and Birnbaum & Saunders [3].

references.text: Z. W. Birnbaum, S. C. Saunders, "A new family of life distributions", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 6, pp. 319-327, 1969.

references.title:
Estimation for a family of
life distributions with applications to fatigue

context.text: We analyze four data sets: two of them have been simulated, and the other two correspond to real data obtained from Birnbaum & Saunders [4].
The data S21, and S31 are available in Birnbaum & Saunders [4], and also in the \${\tt bs}\$ package by using the commands \${\tt data(psi21)}\$, and \${\tt data(psi31)}\$, respectively.

references.text: Z. W. Birnbaum, S. C. Saunders, "Estimation for a family of life distributions with applications to fatigue", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 6, pp. 328-347, 1969.

references.title:
Reliability bounds and critical
time for the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution

context.text: As mentioned, the BS model belongs to the upside-down (or \$\cap\$-shaped) class, and its fr approaches \$1/[2\alpha^{2}\beta]\$ as \$t\rightarrow\infty\$; see Chang & Tang [5].

links.abstract: The Birnbaum-Saunders distribution, under certain conditions, can be used to model the fatigue failure-time caused by the catastrophic crack size. Reliability bounds for the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution and point and interval estimates for the critical time of the failure (hazard)-rate are discussed. The confidence intervals are constructed under the assumption that both parameters are unknown. This method is not affected by censoring, as long as confidence intervals for the parameters can be ...

references.text: D. S. Chang, L. C. Tang, "Reliability bounds and critical time for the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 42, pp. 464-469, 1993.

references.title:
Stochastic models of failure
in random environments

context.text: In this respect, the studies by Desmond [6], Owen & Padgett [24], Volodin & Dzhungurova [31], Díaz-García & Leiva [7], Vilca & Leiva [32], Owen [25], and Leiva et al. [20], can be mentioned.

In spite of the doubtless utility, applicability, and popularity of the BS distribution, it was constructed under restrictive conditions that may not be valid for certain applications, such as those mentioned by Mann et al. [21, p. 152], and Desmond [6].

The second approach allows some generalizations of the BS distribution, simply by replacing with other distributions the standard \$s\$-normal model of the random variable \$X\$ given in (1); see Desmond [6].

links.abstract: The 2-parameter family of probability distributions introduced by Birnbaum and Saunders characterizes the fatigue failure of materials subjected to cyclic stresses and strains. It is shown that the methods of accelerated life testing are applicable to the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution for analyzing accelerated lifetime data, and the (inverse) power law model is used due to its justification for describing accelerated fatigue failure in metals. This paper develops the (inverse) power law acceler...

references.text: W. J. Owen, W. J. Padgett, "A Birnbaum-Saunders accelerated life model", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 49, pp. 224-229, 2000.

A new three-parameter extension
to the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution

context.text: In this respect, the studies by Desmond [6], Owen & Padgett [24], Volodin & Dzhungurova [31], Díaz-García & Leiva [7], Vilca & Leiva [32], Owen [25], and Leiva et al. [20], can be mentioned.
Following this approach, Owen [25] derived a new version of the BS distribution considering crack extensions modeled by a long memory stochastic process.

links.abstract: The Binrbaum-Saunders (B-S) distribution was derived in 1969 as a lifetime model for a specimen subjected to cyclic patterns of stresses and strains, and the ultimate failure of the specimen is assumed to be due to the growth of a dominant crack in the material. The derivation of this model will be revisited, and because the assumption of independence of crack extensions from cycle to cycle can be quite unrealistic, one new model will be derived by relaxing this independence assumption. Here, th...

references.text: W. J. Owen, "A new three-parameter extension to the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 55, pp. 475-479, 2006.
